bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: Robert Thaddeus Ellett served as an assistant surgeon in the Confederate States Army from 1863-65, at which time he was assigned to a hospital in Montgomery White Sulphur Springs, VA. Prior to his appointment as assistant surgeon, Ellett served as Captain of the Pamunkey Artillery, Virginia Heavy Artillery, Confederate States Army from May, 1861 until his resignation on September 3, 1862. Two months after the Civil War, Ellett was pardoned at Charleston, West Virginia on June 14, 1865 as a Surgeon, Provisional Army of the Confederate States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Ellett family papers consist of 35 correspondence letters written by Dr. Robert Thaddeus Ellett (1826-1904) who served as assistant surgeon in White Sulphur Springs, Virginia, for the Confederate States during the Civil War. His letters are written to Sue French of Pearisburg, who would later become Ellett's wife.

The Ellett collection also includes one ledger of Ellett's medical accounts, categorized by patient. Other items include biographical and family history information, photos, clippings, a 1961 dedication to Col. W. H. French marker program, DAR applications, and "The Family Album," an eleven page typescript.
